name: Social Energy
definition: Your preference for social interaction versus solitary work. This measures how you recharge—through connection with others or through quiet reflection.
extreme_low: Highly introverted; prefers working alone; drains energy from social interaction
extreme_high: Highly extroverted; energized by constant social interaction; may struggle working alone
usual_behavior_description: How socially engaged you typically are in your day-to-day work and life
needs_description: The amount of social interaction you need to feel energized and fulfilled
stress_triggers: Gap: Too much social interaction when you need solitude (or vice versa)
Forced collaboration when you prefer independent work
Isolation when you crave social connection
Being in the spotlight when you prefer working behind the scenes

scale_labels.low: Prefers working alone, recharges through solitude
scale_labels.high: Energized by people, thrives in social settings

extreme_low: Completely isolated work with no human interaction
extreme_high: Constant social interaction with no time for independent work
usual_behavior_description: How much social interaction and collaboration you naturally seek in your daily work
needs_description: The amount of social interaction and teamwork you require to feel energized and fulfilled

name: Physical Energy
definition: Your preference for physical activity, hands-on work, and kinesthetic engagement versus sedentary, desk-based work.
extreme_low: Prefers sedentary, desk-based work with minimal physical activity
extreme_high: Requires physical movement, hands-on work, and active engagement

usual_behavior_description.low: You typically prefer work that involves mental focus over physical activity. You're comfortable in office or desk-based settings and don't require much physical movement throughout your day.
usual_behavior_description.medium: You appreciate a balance between physical activity and sedentary work. You function well in environments that allow some movement but don't require constant physical engagement.
usual_behavior_description.high: You thrive when your work involves physical activity, movement, or hands-on tasks. Sitting at a desk all day can feel constraining for you.

needs_description: The level of physical activity and movement you need in your work environment to feel energized and satisfied.
stress_triggers: Being confined to a desk for extended periods without movement
Work that doesn't allow for physical activity or hands-on engagement
Environments that require sitting still for long periods

scale_labels.medium: Balanced need for movement and desk work
scale_labels.high: Thrives with physical activity and movement

name: Emotional Energy
definition: Your typical level of emotional expressiveness and enthusiasm in daily interactions. This reflects how openly you display feelings and how emotionally engaged you are with your work.
extreme_low: Reserved, controlled emotional expression, prefers rational analysis
extreme_high: Highly expressive, passionate, wears emotions openly
usual_behavior_description: How emotionally expressive and enthusiastic you typically appear to others in your daily work.
needs_description: The level of emotional expression and passion you need from your work environment and colleagues to feel energized.
stress_triggers: Being forced to suppress emotions or maintain constant composure
Working in emotionally flat or overly reserved environments
Lack of authentic expression or emotional connection
extreme_low: Highly reserved, prefer minimal emotional display in professional settings
extreme_high: Highly expressive, wear emotions openly, energized by emotional connection
usual_behavior_description: How much emotion and enthusiasm you typically display in your daily interactions
needs_description: The level of emotional expressiveness and passion you need from your environment to feel engaged
stress_triggers: Mismatch between your natural expression and environment expectations
Being forced to be overly formal when you prefer warmth
Being pushed to share feelings when you prefer reserve

name: Self-Consciousness
definition: Your awareness of and concern about how others perceive you. This reflects your sensitivity to social evaluation and your comfort with being in the spotlight.
extreme_low: Highly self-assured, rarely concerned with others' opinions, comfortable being the center of attention
extreme_high: Very self-aware and sensitive to others' perceptions, may overthink social situations
usual_behavior_description: How self-conscious or self-assured you typically appear to others in your day-to-day interactions.
needs_description: The level of privacy, autonomy, or public recognition you require to feel comfortable and perform at your best.
stress_triggers: Being put on the spot unexpectedly
Public criticism or negative feedback
High-visibility situations without preparation
Feeling judged or evaluated constantly

name: Assertiveness
definition: Your tendency to take charge, express opinions directly, and influence others. High assertiveness indicates comfort with leadership and directiveness; low indicates preference for following or supporting.
extreme_low: Very passive, avoids leadership, prefers others to decide
extreme_high: Very directive, takes charge immediately, may dominate
usual_behavior_description: How assertive you typically appear to others in your day-to-day interactions.
needs_description: The level of assertiveness you need from your environment and others around you to feel comfortable and perform optimally.
stress_triggers: Being forced into leadership roles when you prefer following
Having your authority questioned or undermined
Environments that don't match your natural assertiveness level
Pressure to be more or less directive than feels natural

name: Social Energy
definition: Your preference for social interaction and group activities versus solitary work. Measures how much you derive energy from being around others.
extreme_low: Strongly prefers working alone; finds frequent social interaction draining; needs significant alone time to recharge.
extreme_high: Gains energy from constant social interaction; uncomfortable with extended periods of solitary work; seeks collaborative environments.
usual_behavior_description: How social and collaborative you typically are in your day-to-day work and interactions.
needs_description: The level of social interaction and collaboration you require to feel energized and fulfilled.
stress_triggers: Too much forced social interaction (for low scorers)
Too much isolation or solo work (for high scorers)
Mismatch between preferred interaction level and actual work environment
Being in roles that don't match your social energy needs

scale_labels.mid: Balance between solo and collaborative work
scale_labels.high: Thrive on team interaction and collaboration

extreme_low: Strongly prefers working alone, minimal social interaction, independent tasks
extreme_high: Thrives in constant collaboration, energized by group work, avoids solo tasks
usual_behavior_description: How socially engaged you typically are in work settings—from independent work to constant collaboration
needs_description: The amount of social interaction and collaborative work you need to perform at your best
stress_triggers: Mismatch between actual and needed social interaction
Forced collaboration when you need solitude (or vice versa)
Isolation when you need team energy
Over-stimulation in highly social environments

name: Physical Energy
definition: Your natural activity level, preference for physical movement, and need for dynamic versus sedentary work environments.
extreme_low: Prefers calm, sedentary work; minimal physical activity; thoughtful, measured pace
extreme_high: High activity level; constantly moving; thrives in dynamic, fast-paced environments
usual_behavior_description: Your typical energy level and preference for movement versus stillness in work
needs_description: The amount of physical activity and environmental dynamism you require to stay engaged
stress_triggers: Being confined to a desk when you need movement
Overly fast-paced environments when you prefer calm
Lack of variety in physical activity
Mismatch between your energy level and job demands

name: Emotional Energy
definition: Your emotional expressiveness, intensity of feelings, and how you process and display emotions in professional settings.
extreme_low: Reserved emotional expression; logical, detached approach; minimal emotional display
extreme_high: Highly expressive; wears heart on sleeve; emotions visible and influential in decisions
usual_behavior_description: How emotionally expressive you typically are and how much you let feelings influence your work
needs_description: The degree of emotional authenticity and expression you need to feel comfortable and effective
stress_triggers: Pressure to suppress authentic emotional responses
Overly emotional environments when you prefer logic
Dismissal of emotional considerations in decisions
Expectation to show emotions you don't naturally express

name: Self-Consciousness
definition: Your level of self-awareness, concern about others' perceptions, and tendency toward introspection versus external focus.
extreme_low: Low self-monitoring; unconcerned with others' opinions; acts naturally without overthinking
extreme_high: Highly self-aware; carefully manages impression; deeply concerned with how others perceive actions
usual_behavior_description: How much you monitor yourself and consider others' perceptions in your behavior
needs_description: The level of self-reflection and awareness of social dynamics you require to feel secure
stress_triggers: Public speaking or high-visibility situations (high self-consciousness)
Lack of feedback on how you're being perceived
Social situations without clear expectations
Pressure to 'not care' what others think when you naturally do

name: Assertiveness
definition: Your tendency to take charge, voice opinions directly, and drive decisions versus preferring to follow or facilitate.
extreme_low: Passive; defers to others; avoids taking charge; prefers supporting roles
extreme_high: Highly assertive; takes charge naturally; voices opinions directly; drives outcomes
usual_behavior_description: How directly you communicate and how often you take the lead in situations
needs_description: The degree of influence and control you need over decisions and direction to feel effective
stress_triggers: Being forced to lead when you prefer to support
Lack of voice or influence when you need to drive outcomes
Overly passive teams when you need decisive action
Aggressive environments when you prefer collaborative decision-making

name: Insistence
definition: Your preference for having things done your way, maintaining control over processes, and resisting others' influence on your approach.
extreme_low: Highly flexible; easily accommodates others' methods; open to influence and change
extreme_high: Strong preference for own methods; resists external control; insists on specific approaches
usual_behavior_description: How much you prefer to maintain your own methods versus adapt to others' approaches
needs_description: The degree of autonomy and control over your work methods you require to feel comfortable
stress_triggers: Micromanagement or excessive oversight
Being forced to follow processes that don't match your style
Lack of structure when you need clear methods
Too much autonomy when you prefer guidance

name: Incentives
definition: Your motivation by external rewards, recognition, and competitive success versus intrinsic satisfaction and personal meaning.
extreme_low: Intrinsically motivated; values personal meaning; unconcerned with external rewards or recognition
extreme_high: Highly motivated by rewards, recognition, status, and competitive achievement
usual_behavior_description: What drives you—external validation and rewards or internal satisfaction and purpose
needs_description: The type and frequency of recognition or intrinsic fulfillment you need to stay motivated
stress_triggers: Lack of recognition when you need external validation
Over-emphasis on competition when you value collaboration
Purely extrinsic rewards when you seek meaning
Lack of tangible incentives when they motivate you

name: Restlessness
definition: Your need for variety, change, and novelty versus preference for routine, stability, and predictability.
extreme_low: Prefers routine and stability; uncomfortable with frequent change; values predictability
extreme_high: Craves variety and novelty; bored by routine; constantly seeks new experiences and challenges
usual_behavior_description: How much you seek out change and new experiences versus preferring familiar patterns
needs_description: The amount of variety and novelty you require to stay engaged versus stability to feel secure
stress_triggers: Excessive routine when you crave variety
Constant change when you need stability
Boredom from repetitive tasks
Unpredictability when you prefer clear patterns

name: Thought
definition: Your preference for abstract, theoretical thinking versus concrete, practical application and hands-on problem-solving.
extreme_low: Highly practical; prefers concrete tasks; learns by doing; focuses on immediate application
extreme_high: Abstract thinker; enjoys theory and concepts; prefers understanding principles before application
usual_behavior_description: How you approach problems—through abstract concepts or practical, hands-on methods
needs_description: The balance of theoretical understanding versus practical application you need to learn and work effectively
stress_triggers: Too much theory without practical application
Lack of conceptual framework when you need one
Pressure to theorize when you prefer hands-on work
Purely concrete tasks when you need intellectual stimulation
